Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was sweeping up hair clippings when I saw my little brother outside, skateboard in hand, eyeing the steep, cracked ramp at the edge of the parking lot. He caught my gaze through the window and grinned, clearly about to try something reckless. My heart thudded with worry—he’d promised to wait for me before trying new tricks, but I could see he was itching to go. At the same moment, the bell above the salon door jingled. A woman stepped in, clutching her purse, her eyes darting nervously around the room. I knew I was supposed to greet her warmly, help her feel at ease, and show her to a chair. My boss always said first impressions mattered most. But my brother was already setting his board down, and I could almost hear my mom’s voice in my head: “Look out for him, always.” I stood frozen, torn between rushing outside to stop him and turning to welcome my anxious client, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
